J	El Manira, A; Grillner, S				El Manira, Abdel; Grillner, Sten			Motion with Direction and Balance	NEURON			English	Editorial Material							LARVAL ZEBRAFISH; ADULT ZEBRAFISH; NEURONS; INTERNEURONS; RECRUITMENT; NETWORKS; CIRCUITS; PATTERN	In this issue of Neuron, three papers, Severi et al. (2014), Thiele et al. (2014), and Wang and McLean (2014), examine the descending circuitry involved in coordinating locomotor behavior in larval zebrafish. Visually evoked locomotor and steering movements in zebrafish are mediated by neurons in the nucleus of the medial longitudinal fascicle (nMLF) that project directly to spinal motoneurons. The final motor output induced by nMLF will involve integration in the hindbrain and premotor circuits in the spinal cord. J	Kaplan, DM; Snyder, LH				Kaplan, David M.; Snyder, Lawrence H.			The Need for Speed: Eye-Position Signal Dynamics in the Parietal Cortex	NEURON			English	Editorial Material							NEURONS; MOVEMENTS; SACCADES; REPRESENTATION; NETWORKS; SPACE; GAZE	Accurate eye-position signals are critically important for localizing targets in space when the eyes move. In this issue of Neuron, Xu et al. (2012) provide evidence that eye-position gain fields in area LIP remain spatially inaccurate for some time after a saccade, indicating they are not updated rapidly enough to play a role in the computation of target locations for upcoming saccades. J	Lemke, G; Lamar, E; Pafterson, J				Lemke, Greg; Lamar, Elise; Patterson, John			Isolation and Analysis of the Gene Encoding Peripheral Myelin Protein Zero	NEURON			English	Editorial Material								We have isolated the gene encoding the Schwann cell glycoprotein P(0), the major structural protein of the peripheral myelin sheath. In rats and mice, this gene is split into six exons distributed over 7 kb of DNA. The segregation of these exons is consistent with the functional segregation of the P(0) protein into extracellular, membrane-spanning, and cytoplasmic domains. We find that the P(0) extracellular domain is similar in structure to a single immunoglobulin variable region domain. In contrast to prototypical immunoglobulin domains, however, this P(0) domain is encoded by two exons, the partitioning of which provides genetic evidence for the evolution of immunoglobulin-related domains from an ancestral half-domain. We also describe procedures for transfection of cultures of nontransformed rat Schwann cells and use these procedures to show that the Schwann cell-specific expression of the P(0) gene is controlled by cis-acting elements localized upstream of exon 1.	[Lemke, Greg; Lamar, Elise; Patterson, John] Salk Inst, Mol Neurobiol Lab, San Diego, CA 92138 USA	Salk Institute	Lemke, G (corresponding author), Salk Inst Biol Studies, La Jolla, CA 92037 USA.	lemke@salk.edu							0	2	2	0	5	CELL PRESS	CAMBRIDGE	600 TECHNOLOGY SQUARE, 5TH FLOOR, CAMBRIDGE, MA 02139 USA	0896-6273			NEURON	Neuron	NOV 6	2008	60	3					403	403		10.1016/j.neuron.2008.10.034	http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2008.10.034			1	Neurosciences	Science Citation Index Expanded (SCI-EXPANDED)	Neurosciences & Neurology	373PI	18995810	Bronze			2022-12-17	WOS:000260983800007

Au naturel	NEURON			English	Editorial Material							LATERAL GENICULATE-NUCLEUS; RETINAL GANGLION-CELLS; NEURAL CODE; CONTRAST; ADAPTATION; VISION; BRAIN; FIELD	Although adaptation is a ubiquitous property of neurons in the early visual pathway, the functional consequences in the natural visual environment are unknown. In this issue of Neuron, Mante et al. show, through a comprehensive set of in vivo experiments in the visual thalamus, that the basic functional mechanisms of adaptation that have been well studied with artificial probes capture the neuronal response in the natural environment and are predictable from properties of the visual scene that may be represented by local neural ensembles. J	Ganel, T				Ganel, T			The objects of face perception	NEURON			English	Editorial Material							RECOGNITION; REPETITION; IDENTITY; BRAIN	In a comprehensive series of experiments that combine neural modeling, behavioral data, and fMRI, Jiang et al. (this issue of Neuron) advance a general object and face classification model, based on a feedforward shape-detector architecture. The model accounts for configural face processing as well as for shape-based fMRI activation in the fusiform face area (FFA).
